case_vignette: A 13-year-old girl presents with a cystic lesion that has been on her forearm for several years. Concerned about the lesion, she reports that it may have grown slightly larger in the past year and it is intermittently painful. More recently, a second similar lesion has appeared in close proximity. She denies any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on her skin. Her family history is negative for skin cancer, and she reports no other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals two well-defined 6-mm nodules that are rubbery, slightly tender, and pink on the right proximal ventral forearm. The overlying skin is intact, and there is no associated adenopathy.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a cystic lesion on my forearm that has grown slightly larger over the past year and is sometimes painful. A second similar lesion has also appeared near it recently.
Have you ever had similar cystic lesions elsewhere on your body?
No, I don't have any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on my skin.
Do any of your family members have a history of similar skin issues or any genetic disorders?
No, my family history is negative for skin cancer and there are no other medical conditions reported.
Do the lesions change in appearance or sensation when exposed to factors like heat, cold, or pressure?
The description doesn't specify any changes to the lesions with exposure to heat, cold, or pressure.
Have you noticed any changes in the color or texture of the lesions?
The lesions are pink and rubbery, but there's no specific mention of any changes in color or texture over time.
Have you experienced any other symptoms, such as fever, weight loss, or night sweats?
No, I haven't experienced any other symptoms like fever, weight loss, or night sweats.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma
